1.1.title: How many FTEâ€™s are in your SOC?
1.1.remark: Include both internal and external FTE's

1.2.title: Do you use external employees / contractors in your SOC?
1.2.remark: External employees can be hired experts to fill in vacant positions or perform project activities

1.2.1.title: If yes, specify the number of external FTE's

1.3.title: Does the current size of the SOC meet FTE requirements?
1.3.remark: i.e. is the SOC size sufficient to realize business goals?
guidances: The SOC is either heavily overstaffed or understaffed
The SOC is overstaffed or understaffed
The SOC is somewhat overstaffed or understaffed
The SOC mostly meets FTE requirements
The SOC is staffed to full satisfaction in terms of FTE requirements

1.4.title: Does the SOC meet requirements for internal to external employee FTE ratio?
1.4.remark: Note: requirements do not need to be explicit. Set importance to 'None' if you have no external employees.
guidances: There are either way too few or too many external employees
There are too few or too many external employees
The SOC has somewhat too many or too few external employees
The SOC mostly meets requirements for external employee FTE count
The external employee ratio meets all requirements

1.5.title: Does the SOC meet requirements for internal to external employee skillset?
1.5.remark: i.e. Are there any crucial skills amongst external employees? Set importance to 'None' if you have no external employees
guidances: There are too many skills only present within the external employees
Some required skills are not present internally, and not transferred
Some required skills are not present internally, but being transferred
Most skills are covered with internal employees
All required skills are covered with internal employees as well

1.6.title: Are all positions filled?
1.6.remark: Unfilled positions may be due to deficiencies in the recruitment process
guidances: Not all positions filled, service delivery cannot be assured
Sufficient positions filled to ensure service delivery
All positions currently filled, not meeting external ration requirements
All positions currently filled, meeting external ratio requirements

1.7.title: Do you have a recruitment process in place?
1.7.remark: A recruitment process is required to obtain new employees in a market where talent is scarce [1]
guidances: There is no recruitment process in place
Recruitment is performed at an ad-hoc basis
A basic recruitment process is in place
A full recruitment process is in place, but not performing effectively
A full recruitment process is in place and performing effectively

1.8.title: Do you have a talent acquisition process in place?
1.8.remark: Talent recruitment can be vital for SOC success, but talent retaining is equally important
guidances: No talent acquisition process in place
Talent acquisition is performed at an ad-hoc basis
A basic talent acquisition process is in place
A full acquisition process is in place, but not performing effectively
A full acquisition process is in place and performing effectively

1.9.title: Do you have specific KSAOs established for SOC personnel?
1.9.remark: Knowledge, Skills, Abilities and Other attributes (KSAOs) should be in place: technical, cognitive, social and character [2], [3]
guidances: KSOAs are used ad-hoc in staffing attempts
A basic standardized KSAO set is created
A full KSAO is created, but not actively used in staffing
A full KSAO is created, regularly updated and actively used in staffing

1.10.title: Do you actively seek to create a psychologically safe environment for SOC personnel?
1.10.remark: A psychologically safe environment is an environment where everyone is able to speak their mind and feel valued
guidances: A safe environment is not actively created
Basic awareness of a safe environment exists, but is not implemented
A safe environment has been established, but not actively managed
A safe environment has been established, and actively managed
A safe and actively managed environment exists and is evaluated

2.1.title: Do you formally differentiate roles within the SOC?
2.1.remark: Use the roles in 2.2 to determine if you have all roles required in the SOC
guidances: No roles are used in the SOC
Some roles exist, but are not actively being used
Some roles exist, and are actively being used
All roles are fully in use, but not formalized
All roles are fully in use and formalized

2.2.title: Which of the following roles are present in your SOC?

2.2.1.title: Security Analyst
2.2.1.remark: Primarily responsible for triage and analysis of security alerts

2.2.2.title: Security / Systems Engineer
2.2.2.remark: Primarily responsible for technical / functional maintenance of security systems

2.2.3.title: Forensic Analyst
2.2.3.remark: Primarily responsible for in-depth analysis and security projects

2.2.4.title: Security Architect
2.2.4.remark: Primarily responsible for technical architecture for security systems used within the SOC

2.2.5.title: Threat Intelligence Analyst
2.2.5.remark: Primarily responsible for analysis of threat intelligence

2.2.6.title: Data Scientist
2.2.6.remark: Primarily responsible for big data security analytics

2.2.7.title: SOC Manager
2.2.7.remark: Primarily responsible for managing SOC services

2.2.8.title: Team Leader
2.2.8.remark: Primarily responsible for leading a team of other, for example, analysts and engineers

2.2.9.title: Incident Handler
2.2.9.remark: Primarily responsible for executing security incident management workflows

2.2.10.title: Incident Manager
2.2.10.remark: Primarily responsible for ensuring correct and timely management and escalation of security incidents

2.2.11.title: Penetration Tester
2.2.11.remark: Primarily responsible for testing applications and systems for security weaknesses

2.2.12.title: Detection engineer
2.2.12.remark: Primarily responsible for creating and updating detection analytics

2.2.13.title: Automation engineer
2.2.13.remark: Primarily responsible for automation of repetitive SOC tasks

2.3.title: Do you differentiate tiers within these roles?
2.3.remark: If you have no tiers, and you feel this is not a restriction, select importance 'None'
guidances: No tiers exist within these roles
Some tiers exist, but are not actively being used
Some tiers exist, and are actively being used
All tiers are fully in use, but not formalized
All relevant roles are tiered and formalized

2.4.title: Are all roles sufficiently staffed?
2.4.remark: Consider the staffing levels (desired FTE count) as well as knowledge and experience for all roles
guidances: None of the roles meets FTE requirements
All vital roles and most other roles meet FTE requirements
All roles fully meet FTE requirements

2.5.title: Is there a role-based hierarchy in your SOC?
2.5.remark: If you have no hierarchy, and you feel this is not a restriction, select importance 'None'
guidances: A basic hierarchy exists, but is not fully operational
A basic hierarchy is in place and fully operational
A full hierarchy is in place, but not formalized
A full hierarchy is in place and formalized

2.6.title: Have you formally documented all SOC roles?
2.6.remark: Possible documentation elements can be found in under 2.7
guidances: Single document, full description of SOC roles
Document completed, approved and formally published

2.7.title: Please specify elements in  the role documentation:

2.7.1.title: Role description
2.7.1.remark: A formal description of the role

2.7.2.title: Role tasks
2.7.2.remark: A description of tasks that are part of the role

2.7.4.title: Role expectations
2.7.4.remark: This is an extension of responsibilities. Example expectation: take a pro-active leading role in case of security incidents

2.7.5.title: Required technical skills
2.7.5.remark: e.g. experience with specific technologies or products

2.7.8.title: Required or preferred certifications
2.7.8.remark: e.g. technical security certifications or security management certifications

2.8.title: Are responsibilities for each role understood?
2.8.remark: Responsibilities for each role should be clearly understood by all SOC personnel
guidances: Responsibilities for some roles understood and adhered to
Responsibilities for all roles mostly understood and adhered to
Full understanding of responsibilities formalized in training sessions

2.9.title: Have you documented career progression requirements for each of these roles?
2.9.remark: Career progression for roles can be documented through training, certification, experience and soft skills requirements
guidances: Basic documentation of career progression for roles
Single document, full description of career progression for roles
Document completed, approved and formally published

2.10.title: Do you regularly revise or update the role descriptions?
2.10.remark: To revise is to review and verify whether to documentation is still correct or requires an update
guidances: Documentation is reviewed ad-hoc, not using a structured approach
Documentation is reviewed ad-hoc, using a structured approach
Documentation is regularly and informally reviewed and updated
Documentation is regularly and formally reviewed and updated

3.1.title: Do you have a job rotation plan in place?
3.1.remark: Job rotation can be used to train employees in a variety of tasks and avoid too much routine
guidances: A plan covering some roles is in place, but not operational
A plan covering some roles is in place and operational
A plan covering all roles is in place, but not formalized
A plan covering all roles is in place and formalized

3.2.title: Do you have a career progression process in place?
guidances: No career progression process is in place
A process covering some roles is in place, but not operational
A process covering some roles is in place and operational
A process covering all roles is in place, but not formalized
A process covering all roles is in place and formalized

3.3.title: Do you have a talent management process in place?
3.3.remark: Talent should be adequately managed to retain such staff and fully develop their potential.
guidances: No talent management process in place
Talent management is performed at an ad-hoc basis
A basic talent management process is in place
A full process is in place, but not performing effectively
A full talent management process is in place and performing effectively

3.4.title: Do you have team diversity goals?
3.4.remark: e.g. background diversity, ethnic diversity, gender diversity, etc.
guidances: Diversity goals are recognized but not defined
Diversity goals are defined but not formalized
Diversity goals have been formally defined and are not met
Diversity goals have been formally defined and are met

3.5.title: Have you established team goals?
3.5.remark: Team goals help to bring focus to the team and monitor progress
guidances: Team goals are determined, but not formally documented
Team goals are determined, and formally documented
Team goals are determined and documented, but not tracked
Team goals are determined, approved and tracked regularly

3.6.title: Do you document and track individual team member goals?
3.6.remark: Individual team member goals should be set to help grow the employee to full potential
guidances: Individual goals are determined, but not formally documented
Individual goals are determined, and formally documented
Individual goals are determined and documented, but not tracked
Individual goals are determined, approved and tracked regularly

3.7.title: Do you periodically evaluate SOC employees?
3.7.remark: Can also be included  in the regular organization evaluation process
guidances: Periodic evaluation is performed in an ad-hoc fashion
Periodic evaluation is performed in a structured fashion
Periodic evaluation is performed, but results are not used structurally
Periodic evaluation is performed, results are used for personal growth

3.8.title: Do you have a 'new hire' process in place?
3.8.remark: i.e. a defined process to quickly let new employees find their place and perform well in the SOC
guidances: No new hire process in place
New hire training is done in an ad-hoc fashion
A process is in place, but does not cover all aspects
An informal process covering people, process and technology is in place
A formal process covering people, process and technology is in place

3.9.title: Are all SOC employees subjected to screening?
3.9.remark: Personnel screening is performed to avoid infiltration or misbehaviour by SOC employees
guidances: Basic screening performed in ad-hoc fashion
Basic screening procedure in place, applied structurally
Full screening procedure in place, applied structurally, not formalized
Formal screening procedure and background checks applied structurally

3.10.title: Do you measure employee satisfaction for improving the SOC?
3.10.remark: Employee satisfaction should be taken seriously as lack of satisfaction may lead to key personnel leaving
guidances: Employee satisfaction is measured in an ad-hoc fashion
Satisfaction is usually measured, but not embedded in processes
Employee satisfaction is measured, not used for improvement
Employee satisfaction measured periodically and used for improvement

3.11.title: Are there regular 1-on-1 meetings between the SOC manager and the employees?
3.11.remark: Such informal 1-on-1 conversations are used to coach employees and help the SOC manager gain insight in personal challenges
guidances: 1-on-1 meetings are not held within the SOC
1-on-1 meetings are held on ad-hoc basis
Formal 1-on-1 meetings are regularly held, results are not structured
1-on-1 meetings are regularly held and used for coaching and growth

3.12.title: Do you perform regular teambuilding exercises?
3.12.remark: Teambuilding exercises are used to promote collaboration between individuals in the team and to raise team spirit
guidances: No team building exercises are performed
Exercises are performed in an ad-hoc fashion
Exercises are usually performed, but not embedded in processes
Exercises are regularly done, but not focused on improvement
Exercises are regularly done and focused on improving team dynamics

3.13.title: Do you perform regular teambuilding exercises with other teams relevant to the SOC?
3.13.remark: In multi-team systems (MTS), the SOC collaborates with other teams. Use cross-team teambuilding to maximize performance
guidances: No MTS team building exercises are performed
MTS exercises are performed in an ad-hoc fashion
MTS exercises are usually performed, but not embedded in processes
MTS exercises are regularly done, but not focused on improvement
MTS exercises done regularly and focused on improving team dynamics

3.14.title: Do you periodically evaluate team performance?
3.14.remark: Besides individual performance, team performance and dynamics are also important to measure and improve on
guidances: Periodic evaluation is performed in an ad-hoc fashion
Periodic evaluation is performed in a structured fashion
Periodic evaluation is performed, but results are not used structurally
Periodic evaluation is performed, results are used for team growth

4.1.title: Do you have a formal knowledge management process in place?
4.1.remark: Formal knowledge management helps to optimize knowledge creation and distribution
guidances: A knowledge management process is not in place
Knowledge management is done in an ad-hoc fashion
A basic process is in place, that covers some knowledge aspects
An informal process is in place that covers most knowledge aspects
A formal process is in place, covering all knowledge aspects

4.2.title: Do you have a skill matrix in place?
4.2.remark: A matrix may consist of: SOC skills, SOC employees and skill levels (novice, intermediate, expert)
guidances: A skill matrix is not in place
A basic skill matrix is in place, but incomplete
A complete skill matrix is in place, not approved
A complete skill matrix is in place and approved, not regularly updated
A complete skill matrix is in place, approved and regularly updated

4.3.title: Please specify elements of the skill matrix:

4.3.1.title: All SOC employees
4.3.1.remark: The skill matrix should cover all SOC employees, both internal and external

4.3.2.title: Hard skills
4.3.2.remark: e.g. ability to effectively use analysis tools

4.3.4.title: Skill levels (novice, intermediate, expert)
4.3.4.remark: Determining and documenting skill levels helps to identify areas where limited expertise is available

4.4.title: Is the skill matrix actively used for team and personal improvement?
4.4.remark: Personal improvement is essential, team improvement requires insight in team dynamics and skill distribution
guidances: Matrix used for improvement in an ad-hoc fashion
Matrix used to improve some personal and team results
Matrix used to improve all personal and team results
Matrix used to improve personal and team results, improvements tracked

4.5.title: Do you have a knowledge matrix in place?
guidances: A knowledge matrix is not in place
A basic knowledge matrix is in place, but incomplete
A complete knowledge matrix is in place, not approved
A complete knowledge matrix is in place and approved, not regularly updated
A complete knowledge matrix is in place, approved and regularly updated

4.6.title: Please specify elements of the knowledge matrix:

4.6.1.title: All SOC employees
4.6.1.remark: The knowledge matrix should cover all SOC employees, both internal and external

4.6.2.title: All relevant knowledge areas
4.6.2.remark: Knowledge for service delivery: technical (i.e. support), functional (i.e. configuration) and foundational (e.g. networking, encryption)

4.6.3.title: Knowledge levels (novice, intermediate, expert)
4.6.3.remark: Determining and documenting knowledge levels helps to identify areas where limited expertise is available

4.7.title: Is the knowledge matrix actively used to determine training and education needs?
4.7.remark: The matrix should be used as a means to identify and resolve knowledge gaps
guidances: Matrix not used for identification of training needs
Matrix used for training identification in an ad-hoc fashion
Matrix used to identify training needs, but not for all employees
Matrix used to identify all training needs, but not tracked for execution
Matrix structurally used to identify training needs, training tracked

4.8.title: Have you documented SOC team member abilities?
4.8.remark: Besides knowledge and skills, team member abilities are also important to document
guidances: Documentation only covers some employees' abilities
Documentation covers the most relevant abilities for the team
All employee abilities documented, but is not regularly updated
All employee abilities documented, and regularly updated

4.9.title: Do you regularly assess and revise the knowledge management process?
4.9.remark: This refers to the knowledge management process as a whole
guidances: Documentation is reviewed ad-hoc, not using a structured approach
Documentation is reviewed ad-hoc, using a structured approach
Documentation is regularly and informally reviewed and updated
Documentation is regularly and formally reviewed and updated

4.10.title: Is there effective tooling in place to support knowledge documentation and distribution?
4.10.remark: Such tooling can help to avoid investigation similar issues multiple times by integrating into the security monitoring process
guidances: Tooling is in place, but used in an ad-hoc fashion
Tooling is in place, and used regularly
Tooling is in place and use of the tool is embedded in processes
Tooling is in place and optimized for knowledge management purposes

5.1.title: Do you have a training program in place?
5.1.remark: A training program is used to ensure a minimal level of knowledge for employees
guidances: A training program is not in place
A training program some roles is in place, but not operational
A training program covering some roles is in place and operational
A training program covering all roles is in place, but not formalized
A training program covering all roles is in place and formalized

5.2.title: Please specify elements of the training program:

5.2.1.title: Training on the Job
5.2.1.remark: Training on the job can be done internally by senior employees or using external consultants

5.2.2.title: Product-specific training
5.2.2.remark: Product-specific training may be required for new technologies or complex solutions

5.2.4.title: Role-based specific training
5.2.4.remark: For example: security analysis training for the security analyst role

5.2.5.title: Soft-skill training
5.2.5.remark: To complement hard skills, soft skills should be trained as well

5.2.6.title: Formal education
5.2.6.remark: Formal education may be university or university college degrees

5.3.title: Do you have a certification program in place?
5.3.remark: A certification program is used to provide a demonstrable minimum level of knowledge and skills
guidances: A certification program is not in place
A certification program some roles is in place, but not operational
A certification program covering some roles is in place and operational
A certification program covering all roles is in place, but not formalized
A certification program covering all roles is in place and formalized

5.4.title: Please specify elements of the certification program:

5.4.1.title: Internal certification track
5.4.1.remark: Internal certifications may be in place to demonstrate knowledge of company processes and policies

5.4.2.title: External certification track
5.4.2.remark: Certification track with external certification organizations (e.g. ISACA, (ISC)2, SANS

5.4.3.title: Re-certification track (continuous education)
5.4.3.remark: Permanent education (PE) may be part of the certification itself

5.5.title: Is the training and certification program connected to evaluation and career progression?
5.5.remark: e.g. certain training and certifications are required to grow from a junior level function to a more senior level function
guidances: The programs are connected in an ad-hoc fashion
The programs are regularly used, but not embedded in processes
The programs are mostly aligned, but not formally
The programs are formally embedded in evaluation and progression

5.6.title: Is there a reserved budget for education and training?
5.6.remark: i.e. a fixed percentage of the total SOC budget that is allocated for education and cannot be used for other purposes
guidances: Insufficient budget is allocated for the team as a whole
Sufficient budget is allocated for the team as a whole
Employees have sufficient budget, not encouraged to attend training
Employees have sufficient budget, encouraged to attend training

5.7.title: Is there a reserved amount of time for education and training?
5.7.remark: This is an extension of education budget
guidances: Insufficient time is allocated for the team as a whole
Sufficient time is allocated for the team as a whole
Employees have sufficient time, but not encouraged to attend training
Employees have sufficient time, and encouraged to attend training

5.8.title: Do you have regular workshops for knowledge development?
5.8.remark: Workshops are an informal way of distributing knowledge
guidances: Workshops are held in an ad-hoc fashion
Workshops are held regularly, not aligned with knowledge & training
Workshops are held regularly and aligned with knowledge & training

5.9.title: Do you regularly revise and update the training and certification programs?
5.9.remark: Training and certification must be a relevant reflection of SOC knowledge and skill requirements
guidances: Programs are reviewed ad-hoc, not using a structured approach
Programs are reviewed ad-hoc, using a structured approach
Programs are regularly and informally reviewed and updated
Programs are regularly and formally reviewed and updated

1.1.title: Have you identified the main business drivers?
1.1.remark: Example business drivers: cyber crime prevention, risk reduction, law / regulation, audit / compliance, business continuity
guidances: Some business drivers have been identified
Most business drivers have been identified
All business drivers are well known within the SOC

1.2.title: Have you documented the main business drivers?
1.2.remark: Documentation of business drivers is important for demonstrable business alignment
guidances: Single document, full description of business drivers
Document completed, approved and formally published

1.3.title: Do you use business drivers in the decision making process?
1.3.remark: e.g. to determine priorities or make decisions regarding the on-boarding of new services or operations
guidances: Business drivers are not part of decision making
Business drivers are referred to on an ad-hoc basis
Business drivers are occasionally used in decisions
Business drivers are used in most decisions
Business drivers are used in all relevant decisions

1.4.title: Do you regularly check if the current service catalogue is aligned with business drivers?
1.4.remark: i.e. do you check for services or operations that outside the scope of business drivers?
guidances: Service catalogue has not been checked for alignment
Alignment is performed on an ad-hoc basis
Alignment was performed but not maintained
Alignment is performed and maintained regularly
Every change in the catalogue is checked against drivers

1.5.title: Have the business drivers been validated with business stakeholders?
1.5.remark: Business stakeholders can be C-level management
guidances: Business drivers have not been validated
Basic awareness of SOC drivers exists among stakeholders
Stakeholders informally informed of business drivers
Alignment of SOC drivers with stakeholders is performed
Business drivers are formally validated by stakeholders

2.1.title: Have you identified the SOC customers?
2.1.remark: Types of customers, customer requirements / expectations, etc.
guidances: All customers are identified, including relevance and context

2.2.title: Please specify your customers:
2.2.remark: Use this a guideline for answering 2.1 This is also potentially useful for insights and comparison with previous assessments

2.2.1.title: Legal
2.2.1.remark: Legal department, may be a stakeholder for privacy, or may request forensic investigation to the SOC

2.2.2.title: Audit
2.2.2.remark: The audit department can be supported by logging provided by the SOC

2.2.3.title: Engineering / R&D
2.2.3.remark: The engineering departments deal with Intellectual Property that may require additional access monitoring

2.2.4.title: IT
2.2.4.remark: IT departments can be supported by monitoring for anomalies in their infrastructure and systems

2.2.5.title: Business
2.2.5.remark: Business should be the most important customer, as all SOC activities ultimately support business processes

2.2.6.title: External customers
2.2.6.remark: External customers mostly apply to managed service providers

2.2.7.title: (Senior) Management
2.2.7.remark: Senior management may be a direct SOC customer, depending on organization hierarchy

2.3.title: Have you documented the main SOC customers?
2.3.remark: Formal registration of customer contact details, place in the organization, geolocation, etc.
guidances: Single document, full description of SOC customers
Document completed, approved and formally published

2.4.title: Do you differentiate output towards these specific customers?
2.4.remark: For example, are communication style and contents to Business customers different than that to IT?
guidances: Output is the same for all customers
All important customers receive differentiated output
All customers receive specific output based on context and type

2.5.title: Do you have service level agreements with these customers?
2.5.remark: Service level agreements are used to provide standardized services operating within known boundaries
guidances: No contract in place, ad-hoc agreements made
Basic contract in place, not formally signed of
Contract signed, but not regularly reviewed
Contract signed, approved by- and regularly reviewed with customers

2.6.title: Do you regularly send updates to your customers?
2.6.remark: For example: changes in service scope or delivery. Can also be reports, dashboards, etc.
guidances: Ad-hoc updates sent to some customers
Frequent updates sent to most customers
Periodical updates sent to all customers
Periodical updates sent and discussed with all customers

2.7.title: Do you actively measure and manage customer satisfaction?
2.7.remark: Understanding customer satisfaction will help to better align with business needs
guidances: Customer satisfaction not measured or managed
Customer satisfaction managed in ad-hoc fashion
Customer satisfaction metrics defined, not applied structurally
Customer satisfaction measured structurally, not actively managed
Customer satisfaction fully managed and improved over time

3.1.title: Does the SOC have a formal charter document in place?
guidances: Single charter, full description of SOC strategic elements
Charter completed, approved and formally published

3.2.title: Please specify elements of the charter document:

3.2.1.title: Mission
3.2.1.remark: A SOC mission should be established to provide insight into the reason for existence of the SOC

3.2.2.title: Vision
3.2.2.remark: A vision should be created to determine long-term goals for the SOC

3.2.3.title: Strategy
3.2.3.remark: A strategy should be in place to show how to meet goals and targets set by mission and vision

3.2.4.title: Service Scope
3.2.4.remark: Service scope is documented to provide insight into SOC service delivery

3.2.5.title: Deliverables
3.2.5.remark: The output provided by the SOC, for example: reports, incidents, investigations, advisories, etc.

3.2.7.title: Accountability
3.2.7.remark: Accountability for the SOC for actions taken

3.2.9.title: Stakeholders
3.2.9.remark: All relevant stakeholders for the SOC

3.2.10.title: Objectives / Goals
3.2.10.remark: Objectives and goals should be concrete and measurable so that they are fit for reporting purposes

3.2.11.title: Statement of success
3.2.11.remark: A statement of success is used to determine when the SOC is successful. Should be aligned with goals and objectives

3.3.title: Is the SOC charter document regularly updated?
3.3.remark: Regularity should be matched to your own internal policy. At least yearly is recommended
guidances: Charter is updated on ad-hoc basis
Charter is updated on major changes in business strategy
Charter periodically updated and realigned with business strategy

3.4.title: Is the SOC charter document approved by the business / CISO?
3.4.remark: Approval from the relevant stakeholders will aid in business support for SOC operations
guidances: Business / CISO has basic awareness of the charter
Business / CISO has full awareness of the charter
Business / CISO approves of the content, but not formally
Charter is formally approved by the business / CISO

3.5.title: Are all stakeholders familiar with the SOC charter document contents?
3.5.remark: Making stakeholders aware of the contents helps in getting organizational support for security operations
guidances: Stakeholders are unfamiliar with the charter
Some stakeholders are aware of the charter, but not its contents
Some stakeholders are aware of the charter and its contents
All stakeholders are aware, not all stakeholders know its contents
All Stakeholders are aware of the charter and its contents

4.1.title: Does the SOC have a governance process in place?
4.1.remark: A governance process is required to determine the way the SOC should be managed
guidances: SOC governance process is not in place
SOC governance is done in an ad-hoc fashion
Several governance elements are in place, but not structurally
Formal governance process is in place that covers most SOC aspects
Formal governance process is in place and covers all SOC aspects

4.2.title: Have all governance elements been identified?
4.2.remark: Possible governance elements can be found in under 4.3
guidances: No governance elements have been identified
Some governance elements are identified and governed ad-hoc
Some governance elements are identified and governed actively
Most governance elements are identified and actively governed
All elements are identified and actively governed

4.3.1.title: Business Alignment
4.3.1.remark: Aligning SOC operations to business needs

4.3.2.title: Accountability
4.3.2.remark: Note that this can be part of the SOC charter document. This does not automatically make it part of the governance process

4.3.3.title: Sponsorship
4.3.3.remark: Can be part of stakeholder management

4.3.4.title: Mandate
4.3.4.remark: Mandate for the SOC should be established so that the SOC can take action in crisis situations

4.3.5.title: Relationships & Third Party Management
4.3.5.remark: Both management of internal and external relationships

4.3.6.title: Vendor Engagement
4.3.6.remark: For example: active involvement of vendors in the creation of a vision and strategy for the SOC

4.3.7.title: Service Commitment
4.3.7.remark: For example: service level agreements and IT controls

4.3.8.title: Project / Program Management
4.3.8.remark: Project management for individual projects within the SOC / program management for larger transitions

4.3.9.title: Continual Improvement
4.3.9.remark: Improvement of the SOC and of SOC management

4.3.10.title: Span of control / federation governance
4.3.10.remark: Especially important for SOC setups where multiple SOCs exist within the same company

4.3.11.title: Outsourced service management
4.3.11.remark: Especially important for hybrid SOC setups. When using outsourcing, SLAs and oversight should be in place

4.3.12.title: SOC KPIs & Metrics
4.3.12.remark: These are discussed in more detail in the Process section regarding reporting

4.3.13.title: SOC risk management
4.3.13.remark: Identification of- and dealing with risk (business, people, process and technology risk) within the SOC

4.3.14.title: Customer Engagement / Satisfaction
4.3.14.remark: Are customers an integral part of your security operations? Is their satisfaction of SOC services every inquired about?

4.4.title: Is cost management in place?
4.4.remark: Managing costs is required to justify budget allocation for the SOC and ensure continued service delivery in the future
guidances: Costs visible, basic budget allocation in place
Costs fully visible and mostly managed, forecasting in place
Costs fully managed, not formally aligned with business stakeholders
Costs fully managed and formally aligned with business stakeholders

4.5.1.title: People cost
4.5.1.remark: Costs associated with employees. Should be managed to prove FTE requirements to stakeholders

4.5.2.title: Process cost
4.5.2.remark: Cost associated with processes. Should be managed to ensure process elements can be delivered

4.5.3.title: Technology cost
4.5.3.remark: Cost associated with technology. Should be managed to prove budget requirements for new technology or replacement

4.5.4.title: Services cost
4.5.4.remark: Cost associated with service delivery. Especially important for managed service providers to ensure a healthy business model

4.5.5.title: Facility cost
4.5.5.remark: Cost associated with facilities used by the SOC

4.5.6.title: Budget forecasting
4.5.6.remark: Forecasting of required budget over time. Should be aligned with business needs; increased spending must be justified

4.5.7.title: Budget alignment
4.5.7.remark: Alignment of budget with business requirements and drivers to ensure balanced spending on the SOC

4.5.8.title: Return on investment
4.5.8.remark: Prove the return on investment to stakeholders to ensure continued budget allocation

4.6.title: Are all governance elements formally documented?
4.6.remark: Formal documentation should be signed off and stored in a quality management system
guidances: Single document, full description of governance elements
Governance document completed, approved and formally published

4.7.title: Are SOC governance meetings regularly held?
4.7.remark: Meetings at different levels (operational, tactical, strategic) should be formalised in Terms of Reference (ToR) and driven by metrics
guidances: Governance meetings held in an ad-hoc fashion
Governance meetings at different levels scheduled and structured
Governance meetings at different levels scheduled, ToR formalised

4.8.title: Is the governance process regularly reviewed?
4.8.remark: Frequency should be matched to your own internal policy. At least yearly is recommended
guidances: Governance process is reviewed in an ad-hoc fashion
Process is reviewed using a structured approach in an ad-hoc fashion
Process is regularly and informally reviewed and updated
Process is regularly and formally reviewed and updated with findings

4.9.title: Is the governance process aligned with all stakeholders?
4.9.remark: Alignment will help the SOC obtain required mandate, budget and management support
guidances: Stakeholders are unfamiliar with the process
Some stakeholders are aware of the process, but not its details
Some stakeholders are aware of the process and its details
All stakeholders are aware, not all stakeholders know its details
All stakeholders are aware of the process and its details

4.10.title: Is the SOC regularly audited or subjected to (external) assessments?
4.10.remark: Frequency should be matched to the SOC policy. At least yearly is recommended. 3rd party assessments have a higher objectivity
guidances: The SOC is assessed in an ad-hoc fashion
The SOC is assessed using a structured approach in an ad-hoc fashion
The SOC is regularly and informally assessed
The SOC is regularly and formally assessed by a third party

4.11.title: Is there an active cooperation with other SOCs (external)?
4.11.remark: Exchange of best practices, intelligence and actions on threats with other SOCs is vital for improving cyber defence
guidances: Some information exchange with external SOCs
Information exchanged regularly, cooperation not formalized
Continuous formalized active cooperation and information exchange

5.1.title: Is there an information security policy in place that supports the SOC activities?
5.1.remark: A clear security policy that supports SOC operations provides guidance and helps to enforce mandate for the SOC in the organisation
guidances: No formal information security policy in place
Information security in place, no mention of SOC activities
Policy in place, SOC activities mentioned without mandate
Policy in place, SOC activities mentioned in detail with mandate
Policy with SOC activities and mandate in place, actively communicated

5.2.title: Has a SOC policy been created?
5.2.remark: A SOC policy is to outline the rules to which SOC personnel and SOC management needs to adhere
guidances: Single document, full description of SOC policy elements
SOC policy document completed, approved and formally published

5.3.title: Please specify elements of the SOC policy

5.3.1.title: Code of conduct
5.3.1.remark: How to behave in the SOC, mandatory and optional meetings, SOC culture, repercussions for non-compliance, etc.

5.3.2.title: Rules of engagement & responsibilities
5.3.2.remark: What activities can and can not be performed as part of the job

5.3.3.title: Review frequency of documentation
5.3.3.remark: What documentation is subjected to review and how often that documentation needs to be reviewed

5.3.4.title: SOC assessment frequency and type
5.3.4.remark: How often the SOC is assessed and in what manner (self-assessment, audit, external assessment, etc.)

5.3.5.title: Knowledge exchange and maintenance
5.3.5.remark: The means (meetings and platforms) for knowledge exchange and rules for maintenance of knowledge bases

5.3.6.title: Exercise frequency
5.3.6.remark: Frequency and type (table top, cyber range, red team, etc.) of exercises in the SOC

5.3.7.title: Usage of TLP
5.3.7.remark: Information exchange protocols. Especially important for collaborations outside the organisation

5.3.8.title: Working agreements
5.3.8.remark: Agreements on length of meetings, length of agile sprints, transparency of completed work, etc.

5.4.title: Is the SOC consulted in the creation and updates of operational security policy?
5.4.remark: Consulting the SOC in the creation of security policy will ensure that SOC activities are properly mentioned and enforceable
guidances: SOC not consulted or informed of policy creation or policy updates
SOC informed of policy creation and updates only
SOC consulted before policy creation and updates, not actively involved
SOC consulted before policy creation and updates, performs reviews
Full involvement of the SOC in the creation of operational security policy

5.5.title: Is a reporting policy for security incidents in place?
5.5.remark: A reporting policy for security incidents will aid the SOC in identifying incidents and threats in the organization
guidances: Policy in place, no mention of the SOC
Policy in place, role of the SOC in security incidents mentioned
Policy in place with all SOC activities, no central point for reporting
Policy & central point for reporting in place, SOC part of the workflow

5.6.title: Is a privacy policy regarding security monitoring of employees in place?
5.6.remark: A privacy policy should state that monitoring of employees is possible within acceptable limits
guidances: Information regarding privacy is scattered across documents
A policy exists, but has not been accepted formally
A formal policy exists, its contents are known to all employees
A formal policy exists, its contents are accepted by all employees

5.7.title: Does the SOC operate in compliance with all applicable privacy laws and regulations?
5.7.remark: Local laws and regulations as well as company policy may apply and should all be considered
guidances: Regulations are not known and the SOC is non-compliant
Some regulations are known and the SOC is non-compliant
Most regulations are known and the SOC is partially compliant
Regulations are fully known and the SOC is mostly compliant
Regulations are fully known and the SOC is fully compliant

5.8.title: Does the SOC cooperate with legal departments regarding privacy matters?
5.8.remark: Cooperation will ensure that the SOC is enabled to perform activities, rather than blocked
guidances: There is no cooperation between the SOC and legal
There is some ad-hoc cooperation between SOC and legal
There is structural cooperation between SOC and legal
Alignment exists between SOC and legal
Full and regular alignment exists between SOC and legal

5.9.title: Are specific procedures in place for dealing with privacy related investigations?
5.9.remark: Privacy related issues require careful examination, especially those potentially leading to court cases
guidances: Single document, full description of privacy investigations
Procedure completed, approved and formally published

5.10.title: Is the SOC aware of all information that it processes and is subject to privacy regulations?
5.10.remark: Such information includes IP addresses, customer identifiers, user names, host names (for personally owned devices), etc.
guidances: The SOC is unaware of any information
The SOC is aware of such information, no formal identification
The SOC is fully aware, some information is formally identified
Most privacy related information is identified and documented
All privacy related information is identified and documented

5.11.title: Is a Privacy Impact Assessment (PIA) regularly conducted?
5.11.remark: Can be used to determine the impact of monitoring on privacy, and can help uncover potential violations
guidances: PIAs are conducted in an ad-hoc fashion
PIAs are conducted using a structured approach in an ad-hoc fashion
PIAs are conducted informally and regularly
PIAs are conducted formally and regularly

1.1.title: Is there a SOC management process in place?
guidances: A SOC management process is not in place
SOC management is done in an ad-hoc fashion
A basic process is in place, that covers some aspects
An informal process is in place that covers most aspects
A formal process is in place, covering all aspects

1.2.title: Are SOC management elements formally identified and documented?
guidances: Basic documentation of SOC management process
Single document, full description of SOC management process
Document completed, approved and formally published

1.3.title: Please specify identified SOC management elements:

guidances: SOC management process is not reviewed
SOC management process is reviewed in an ad-hoc fashion
Process is reviewed using a structured approach in an ad-hoc fashion
Process is regularly and informally reviewed and updated
Process is regularly and formally reviewed and updated with findings

1.5.title: Is the SOC management process aligned with all stakeholders?
guidances: Stakeholders are unfamiliar with the process
Some stakeholders are aware of the process, but not its details
Some stakeholders are aware of the process and its details
All stakeholders are aware, not all stakeholders know its details
All stakeholders are aware of the process and its details

1.6.title: Have you implemented a process for continuous improvement (CI)?
guidances: CI conducted in an ad-hoc fashion
CI conducted structurally, following a defined process
CI conducted structurally, following an approved and measured process

1.7.title: Specify elements of the continuous improvement program:

1.8.title: Have you implemented a process to manage SOC quality assurance (QA)?
guidances: QA conducted in an ad-hoc fashion
QA conducted structurally, following a defined process
QA conducted structurally, following an approved and measured process

1.9.title: Please specify elements of the quality assurance program:

guidances: Architecture conducted in an ad-hoc fashion

SOC architecture process completed, not used consistently decisions
SOC architecture process approved and used actively in decision making

guidances: Single document, full description of SOC exercises
Exercises plan completed, approved and formally published

guidances: No security operations exercises are performed
Exercises are performed on ad-hoc basis
Exercises are sometimes performed in a structured manner

Formal structured exercises are performed regularly

2.1.4.title: Are the results from exercises documented?
guidances: Results documented in a ad-hoc fashion
Results documented in a single document
Results documented using a defined template
Results documented, reviewed and formally approved

2.1.5.title: Is the output from exercises actively used to improve security operations?
guidances: Output not used for improvement purposes
Improvements done in an ad-hoc fashion
Improvements determined, formally assigned, implementation tracked

2.2.1.title: Do you have standard operating procedures?
guidances: No standard operating procedures are in place
Only vital procedures are in place
All procedures are in place, not optimized through feedback
All procedures are in place, up to date and optimized for performance

2.2.2.title: Do you use checklists for recurring activities?
guidances: A basic checklist is used in an ad-hoc fashion

Checklists are used consistently, but not formally signed off
Checklists are used consistently and formally signed off

2.2.3.title: Do you use documented workflows?
guidances: Single document, full description of workflows

guidances: An operational handbook is not in place

2.2.5.title: Have you established an Operational Security (OPSEC) program?

guidances: Problem management is executed in an ad-hoc fashion

2.4.5.title: Do you have a secure physical storage location?

2.4.6.title: Do you have a video wall for monitoring purposes?

2.4.7.title: Do you have a call-center capability for the SOC?

2.4.8.title: Do you have specialized analyst workstations?

2.17.9.remark: Preparation exercises to determine service effectiveness

2.17.16.remark: Assignment of severity to the incident, part of impact and magnitude assessment

guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

2.17.20.title: Communication plan & email templates

2.17.22.title: Secure communication channels
2.17.22.remark: Encrypted and secure communications (includes email and phones) that can be used during incident response

2.17.23.title: (dedicated) information sharing platform
2.17.23.remark: A platform for sharing information regarding the security incident

2.17.26.title: On-site incident response
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

2.17.27.title: Remote incident response
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

2.17.28.title: Third-party escalation

2.17.29.title: Evaluation template
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

2.17.30.title: Reporting template
2.17.30.remark: A template for reporting on the security incident
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

2.17.31.title: Incident closure
2.17.31.remark: Formal closure of the incident, including debriefing sessions

2.17.32.title: Lessons learned extraction for process improvement
2.17.32.remark: Continuous improvement based on previous experiences

guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.7.title: Dynamic malware analysis
3.16.7.remark: Running malware in a controlled environment to determine its characteristics
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.8.title: Tradecraft analysis
3.16.8.remark: Analysis of the tradecraft of the attacker. This includes the tools, tactics, techniques and procedures used by attackers
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.9.title: Historic analysis
3.16.9.remark: Analysis of historic information based on new insights. APTs can span multiple months or years
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.10.title: Network analysis
3.16.10.remark: Analysis of network traffic patterns and packets
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.11.title: Memory analysis
3.16.11.remark: Analysis of end-point memory, for example fileless malware
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.12.title: Mobile device analysis
3.16.12.remark: Capability to perform forensic analysis of mobile devices
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.13.title: Volatile information collection
3.16.13.remark: Collection of volatile information (such as memory; see RFC3227) requires swift response, as evidence may be lost quickly
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.14.title: Remote evidence collection
3.16.14.remark: Capability to remotely collect evidence (files, disk images, memory dumps, etc. ) from target systems
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.15.title: Forensic hardware toolkit
3.16.15.remark: Hardware toolkits will likely at least consist of write-blockers for disk imaging
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.16.title: Forensic analysis software toolkit
3.16.16.remark: Software tools used in forensic analysis
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.17.title: Dedicated analysis workstations
3.16.17.remark: Dedicated workstations loaded with specialized tools should be used to make investigations more efficient
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.18.title: Security analysis & forensics handbook
3.16.18.remark: A handbook that describes security analysis workflows, tools, exceptions, known issues, etc.
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.19.title: Security analysis & forensics workflows
3.16.19.remark: An established workflow for performing security analysis
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.20.title: Case management system
3.16.20.remark: A case management system that supports the analyst workflow
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.21.title: Report templates
3.16.21.remark: Report templates for standardization of investigation reporting
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.22.title: Evidence seizure procedure
3.16.22.remark: Procedure for seizure of evidence in forensic analysis
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.23.title: Evidence transport procedure
3.16.23.remark: Procedure for trusted transport of evidence (e.g. laptops) that preserve the chain of custody
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

3.16.24.title: Chain of custody preservation procedure
3.16.24.remark: Procedures to correctly process evidence, while preserving the chain of custody
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.title: Please specify capabilities and artefacts of the threat intelligence process:

4.15.1.title: Continuous intelligence gathering
4.15.1.remark: A process for continuously gathering relevant intelligence information
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.2.title: Automated intelligence gathering & processing
4.15.2.remark: An automated system that collects and processes security intelligence information
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.3.title: Centralized collection & distribution
4.15.3.remark: A central 'hub' for distributing indicators of compromise to other systems for further processing
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.4.title: Intelligence collection from open / public sources
4.15.4.remark: The use of public sources in the security intelligence process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.5.title: Intelligence collection from closed communities
4.15.5.remark: The use of closed trusted communities in the security intelligence process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.6.title: Intelligence collection from intelligence provider
4.15.6.remark: The use of intelligence providers as a source for the security intelligence process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.7.title: Intelligence collection from business partners
4.15.7.remark: The use of business partners as a source for the security intelligence process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.8.title: Intelligence collection from mailing lists
4.15.8.remark: The use of mailing lists as a source for the security intelligence process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.9.title: Intelligence collection from internal sources
4.15.9.remark: The use of internal intelligence sources for the security intelligence process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.10.title: Structured data analysis
4.15.10.remark: The capability to analyze structured information
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.11.title: Unstructured data analysis
4.15.11.remark: The capability to analyze unstructured information
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.12.title: Past incident analysis
4.15.12.remark: The capability of using past incidents in the threat intelligence process. e.g. connecting new IoCs to past threats
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.13.title: Trend analysis
4.15.13.remark: Analyzing trends in the threat intelligence IoCs observed within the company
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.14.title: Automated alerting
4.15.14.remark: Automated alerting of sightings of observables
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.15.title: Adversary movement tracking
4.15.15.remark: Tracking the movement of attackers to keep track of new tools, tactics, techniques and procedures
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.16.title: Attacker identification
4.15.16.remark: Identification of adversaries based on correlating intelligence indicators and incidents
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.17.title: Threat identification
4.15.17.remark: Identification of threats related to attacker groups
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.18.title: Threat prediction
4.15.18.remark: Prediction of threats based on the information gathered in the threat intelligence process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.19.title: TTP extraction
4.15.19.remark: Extraction of Tactics, Techniques and Procedures (TTP) from observables within the infrastructure
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.20.title: Deduplication
4.15.20.remark: Deduplication of threat intelligence feeds to avoid duplicate events
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.21.title: Enrichment
4.15.21.remark: Enrichment of information with additional sources for a higher level of confidentiality
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.22.title: Contextualization
4.15.22.remark: Addition of context to the threat intelligence process. Context can be vulnerability context, asset criticality, etc.
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.23.title: Prioritization
4.15.23.remark: Prioritization of threat intelligence based on trustworthiness of source, sector relevance, geographic relevance, timeliness, etc.
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.24.title: Threat intelligence reporting
4.15.24.remark: Reporting on threat intelligence findings and activities
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.25.title: Threat landscaping
4.15.25.remark: Creation of a landscape of current and emerging threats for strategic purposes
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.26.title: Forecasting
4.15.26.remark: Forecasting based on trends and incidents
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.27.title: Sharing within the company
4.15.27.remark: Sharing of information with relevant parties within the company
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.28.title: Sharing with the industry
4.15.28.remark: Sharing of information with relevant parties within the same industry
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.29.title: Sharing outside the industry
4.15.29.remark: Sharing of information with relevant parties outside the industry
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.30.title: Sharing in standardized format (e.g. STIX)
4.15.30.remark: Sharing of information in standardized exchange formats, such as STIX
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

4.15.31.title: Management of the CTI infrastructure (Threat Intelligence Platform)
4.15.31.remark: Managing the TIP to optimally support TI efforts
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.title: Please specify capabilities and artefacts of the threat hunting process:

5.16.1.title: Hash value hunting
5.16.1.remark: 'Trivial', lowest added value as these change swiftly
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.2.title: IP address hunting
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.3.title: Domain name hunting
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.4.title: Network artefact hunting
5.16.4.remark: 'Annoying', include network flow, packet capture, proxy logs, active network connections, historic connections, ports and services
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.5.title: Host-based artefact hunting
5.16.5.remark: 'Annoying', includes users, processes, services, drivers, files, registry, hardware, memory, disk activity, network connections, etc.
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.6.title: Adversary tools hunting
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.7.title: Adversary TTP hunting
5.16.7.remark: 'Tough!', requires detailed knowledge of adversaries and their modus operandi
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.8.title: Inbound threat hunting
5.16.8.remark: Hunting for inbound threats such as inbound connections, DNS zone transfers, inbound emails
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.9.title: Outbound threat hunting
5.16.9.remark: Hunting for outbound threats such as C&C traffic, outbound emails
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.10.title: Internal threat hunting
5.16.10.remark: Hunting for threats inside the organization. Hunting may focus on lateral movement or anomalous network connections
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.11.title: Outlier detection
5.16.11.remark: Using statistical methods to detect outliers, such as least frequency of occurrence
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.12.title: Hunting coverage
5.16.12.remark: How well does the hunting process cover your environment? All assets & network traffic, or only partially? Scalability is key
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.13.title: Leveraging of existing tooling
5.16.13.remark: Existing tools may include the SIEM system, firewall analysis tools, etc.
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.14.title: Custom hunting scripts and tools
5.16.14.remark: Any custom scripts to assist the hunting process. May include scripts to scan end-points for particular artifacts
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.15.title: Dedicated hunting platform
5.16.15.remark: Dedicated tooling for the hunting process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.16.title: Continuous hunting data collection
5.16.16.remark: Continuous collection of information can be used to alert on indicators and to preserve system state
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.17.title: Historic hunting
5.16.17.remark: Hunting for indicators that may have been present on end-points in the past. Requires some sort of saved state
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.18.title: Automated hunting
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.19.title: Hunt alerting
5.16.19.remark: Automated alerting based on queries performed in the hunting process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.20.title: Vulnerability information integration
5.16.20.remark: Integration of vulnerability information into the hunting process to provide additional context
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

5.16.21.title: Threat intelligence integration
5.16.21.remark: Integration of threat intelligence information into the hunting process, threat hunts should be driven by threat intelligence
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

6.15.7.title: Incident management integration
6.15.7.remark: Integration of the vulnerability management process with the incident management process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

6.15.10.remark: Integration of the vulnerability management process with the patch management process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

6.15.11.title: Trend identification

7.15.1.title: End-point log collection
7.15.1.remark: Collection of logs from servers and clients

7.15.2.title: Application log collection
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

7.15.3.title: Database log collection
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

7.15.4.title: Network flow data collection
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

7.15.5.remark: Collection of logs from network devices (switches, routers, etc.)
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

7.15.6.remark: Collection of logs from security devices (firewall, remote access gateways, etc.)
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

7.15.7.remark: A central physical or logical entity for processing and aggregating collected logging
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

7.15.8.remark: e.g. short period for large-quantity logging (proxy logging), long period for security logging
